ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Collapsing ear canals
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: High-frequency air-bone gap with normal bone conduction, normal tympanometry, normal acoustic reflexes, and normal OAEs/ABR suggests artifactual loss from supra-aural headphones.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Normal hearing
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by normal ABR, TEOAEs, and bone conduction thresholds.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess hearing sensitivity across frequencies.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
To evaluate middle ear function and compliance.
To assess the acoustic reflex arc and rule out retrocochlear pathology.
To objectively assess the auditory pathway and confirm hearing status.
To assess outer hair cell function and confirm cochlear integrity.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presents with an apparent bilateral high-frequency conductive hearing loss on the audiogram. However, all physiological measures—including tympanometry, acoustic reflexes, ABR, and TEOAEs—are completely normal. The discrepancy between the significant air-bone gap in the high frequencies and the normal objective tests indicates the hearing loss is artifactual, caused by collapsing ear canals under the pressure of supra-aural headphones.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral high-frequency air-conduction loss (40-55 dB HL at 4000-8000 Hz) with normal bone conduction (0 dB HL), creating a significant air-bone gap.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT 15 dB HL (Right) and 20 dB HL (Left); SRS 100% bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally (Static compliance: 0.62 cc Right, 0.59 cc Left).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Present at normal levels (Right: 90/85 dB HL; Left: 90/95 dB HL).

tests.name: ABR
tests.result_summary: All waves normal; interpeak latencies and latency-intensity function normal.

proposed_items: Retest with insert receivers, stock earmolds, or plastic tubing to keep the ear canal open.
Send a letter to the referring physician with the correct audiogram and explanation of findings.
counseling_actions: Explain to parents that the 'hearing loss' was an artifact caused by the headphones collapsing the ear canals.
Demonstrate the canal collapse effect to the parents using an empty earphone cushion.
Reassure the parents and child that hearing is normal.

escalation.rationale_short: To communicate the correct diagnosis of normal hearing and explain the cause of the screening failures.

follow_up_plan.objective: Demonstrate normal hearing thresholds using insert earphones to confirm the diagnosis.

expected_outcome: Identification of collapsing ear canals as the cause of the artifactual high-frequency conductive loss.
